Here's an idea that's relatively easy to implement and experiment with - 
extinction events. I think I'm right in saying that in biological 
evolution mass extinction events are thought to give evolution a bit of 
a kick. E.g. the cambrian explosion 
<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambrian_explosion>. Then there's the 
argument about how far dinosaurs would have developed if they hadn't 
been zapped by a comet and that mammals (or some slug like ancestor of 
mammals anyhow) were able to fill in the gap left behind, amongst other 
lifeforms.

So all we need is some routine that randomly similarly zaps (I believe 
that's the technical term) our populations/species every once in a 
while. You can do this automatically if a search has stagnated for N 
generations ans/or hours, or just have some way of allowing the user to 
trigger an extinction manually. Worth a try I reckon.
